article:
Warner Bros. Discovery
=====================

Warner Bros. Discovery is a multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate. It was formed in 2021 through the merger of WarnerMedia and Discovery, Inc. The company is one of the largest media conglomerates in the world, with a diverse portfolio of brands and assets in film, television, streaming, and publishing.

Background
----------

### 1923–1979

Warner Bros. was founded in 1923 by four brothers: Harry, Albert, Samuel, and Jack Warner. The company started as a small film production studio in Burbank, California, and quickly grew to become one of the major film studios in Hollywood. In the 1950s and 1960s, Warner Bros. expanded into television production, producing popular shows such as "Cheyenne" and "Maverick."

In the 1970s, Warner Bros. began to expand its operations into other areas, including music and publishing. The company acquired Atlantic Records in 1967 and established Warner Books in 1970.

### 1979–1994

In 1979, Warner Bros. merged with Time Inc. to form Time Warner, one of the largest media conglomerates in the world. The merger brought together Warner Bros.' film and television production studios with Time Inc.'s publishing and cable television assets.

During the 1980s and 1990s, Time Warner expanded its operations into new areas, including cable television and theme parks. The company acquired HBO in 1980 and established Warner Bros. Studios in Florida in 1990.

### 1996–2019

In 1996, Time Warner acquired Turner Broadcasting System (TBS), which included the Turner cable networks, the Atlanta Braves baseball team, and the MGM film library. The acquisition brought together Warner Bros.' film and television production studios with Turner's cable networks and film library.

In 2001, Time Warner merged with AOL to form AOL Time Warner. The merger was widely seen as a failure, and the company spun off AOL in 2009.

In 2018, AT&T acquired Time Warner for $85.4 billion, renaming the company WarnerMedia. The acquisition brought together Warner Bros.' film and television production studios with AT&T's telecommunications assets.

History
-------

### Formation and beginning of operations (2021–2022)

In 2021, AT&T announced that it would spin off WarnerMedia and merge it with Discovery, Inc. to form a new company, Warner Bros. Discovery. The merger was completed in April 2022, and the new company began trading on the NASDAQ stock exchange.

Warner Bros. Discovery is led by CEO David Zaslav, who previously served as the CEO of Discovery, Inc. The company's leadership team includes a number of former WarnerMedia and Discovery executives.

In its first year of operation, Warner Bros. Discovery focused on integrating the WarnerMedia and Discovery assets and developing a new strategy for the company. The company announced plans to launch a new streaming service, which would combine the content of HBO Max and Discovery+.

### Turnover and cutbacks (2023–present)

In 2023, Warner Bros. Discovery announced a significant restructuring of the company, which included the elimination of a number of senior executive positions and the consolidation of several business units.

The company also announced plans to cut costs and reduce its debt, which had increased significantly as a result of the merger. The cost-cutting measures included the elimination of a number of jobs and the closure of several offices.

Despite the challenges, Warner Bros. Discovery remains one of the largest and most successful media conglomerates in the world, with a diverse portfolio of brands and assets in film, television, streaming, and publishing.

Assets
------

Warner Bros. Discovery has a diverse portfolio of assets, including:

* Film studios: Warner Bros. Pictures, New Line Cinema, and HBO Films
* Television networks: HBO, TBS, TNT, truTV, and Cartoon Network
* Streaming services: HBO Max and Discovery+
* Publishing: Warner Books and DC Comics
* Music: Atlantic Records and Warner Music Group
* Theme parks: Warner Bros. Studios in Florida and California

Leadership
----------

Warner Bros. Discovery is led by CEO David Zaslav, who previously served as the CEO of Discovery, Inc. The company's leadership team includes a number of former WarnerMedia and Discovery executives, including:

* David Zaslav, CEO
* Gunnar Wiedenfels, CFO
* Ann Sarnoff, CEO of Warner Bros.
* Casey Bloys, CEO of HBO and HBO Max
* Kathleen Finch, CEO of US Networks and Chief Lifestyle Brands Officer

References
----------

External links
---------------

article:
Jerry Lee Lewis
================

Jerry Lee Lewis is an American singer, songwriter, and musician. He is one of the pioneers of rock and roll music, known for his distinctive piano style and hits like "Great Balls of Fire," "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," and "Breathless." With a career spanning over seven decades, Lewis has made significant contributions to the music industry, earning numerous accolades and a permanent place in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

Early life
-----------

Jerry Lee Lewis was born on September 29, 1935, in Ferriday, Louisiana, to Elmo and Mamie Lewis. He was the third of four children, and his family lived in a small farmhouse. Lewis's father, a farmer, also worked as a mechanic and sold bootleg liquor to make ends meet. The family's financial struggles and Lewis's rebellious nature would later influence his music and personal life.

Lewis's musical talents emerged at an early age. He began playing the piano at the age of nine, inspired by the gospel music he heard in church. He also listened to blues and country music, which would later shape his unique style. Lewis's parents supported his musical endeavors, buying him a piano and encouraging him to perform at local events.

Career
--------

Lewis's music career began in the 1950s, when he started performing at local bars and clubs in Louisiana. He eventually moved to Memphis, Tennessee, where he auditioned for Sun Records, a prominent record label at the time.

### J&M Studio

In 1956, Lewis recorded his first single, "Crazy Arms," at J&M Studio in New Orleans. The song was a moderate success, but it was his next single, "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," that brought him widespread attention. The song's success led to Lewis signing with Sun Records, where he would record some of his most famous hits.

### Sun Records

Lewis's time at Sun Records was marked by significant success. He released a string of hits, including "Great Balls of Fire," "Breathless," and "High School Confidential." These songs showcased Lewis's unique piano style, which blended gospel, blues, and country music. Lewis's music was not only popular among teenagers but also gained attention from the music industry, earning him a spot in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

### Marriage controversy

In 1957, Lewis married Myra Gale Brown, his 13-year-old cousin. The marriage was a scandal, and it damaged Lewis's reputation and career. The controversy led to Lewis being blacklisted by radio stations and concert promoters, making it difficult for him to find work.

### Smash Records

In 1963, Lewis signed with Smash Records, where he released several successful albums, including "The Return of Rock" and "The Golden Cream of the Country." Lewis's music during this period was more country-oriented, which helped him regain popularity.

### Live at the Star Club, Hamburg

In 1964, Lewis released a live album, "Live at the Star Club, Hamburg," which is considered one of the greatest live albums of all time. The album captures Lewis's energetic and unpredictable stage presence, showcasing his piano skills and vocals.

### Country comeback

In the 1970s, Lewis made a successful comeback in the country music scene. He released several hit singles, including "What's Made Milwaukee Famous (Has Made a Loser Out of Me)" and "Middle Age Crazy." Lewis's country music was more mellow and polished, but it still maintained his unique style.

### Grand Ole Opry appearance

In 1973, Lewis appeared at the Grand Ole Opry, a prestigious country music venue. The performance was a significant moment in Lewis's career, marking his return to the country music scene.

### The Session and Southern Roots

In the 1970s, Lewis released two critically acclaimed albums, "The Session" and "Southern Roots." These albums showcased Lewis's ability to blend different musical styles, from country to rock to gospel.

### Later career

In the 1980s and 1990s, Lewis continued to release music and perform live. He also made appearances in films and television shows, including the movie "Great Balls of Fire!" which was based on his life. Lewis's later career was marked by ongoing health issues and personal struggles, but he remained a beloved figure in the music industry.

Music legacy
-------------

Lewis's music legacy is significant. He is one of the pioneers of rock and roll music, and his unique piano style has influenced countless musicians.

### Accolades

Lewis has received numerous accolades, including multiple Grammy nominations and inductions into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Country Music Hall of Fame, and the Gospel Music Hall of Fame.

### Piano style

Lewis's piano style is a blend of gospel, blues, and country music. He is known for his energetic and dynamic playing, which has been described as "piano-pounding" and "finger-burning." Lewis's piano style has influenced many musicians, including Elton John, Leon Russell, and Billy Joel.

Personal life
-------------

Lewis's personal life has been marked by controversy and struggle.

### Relationships and children

Lewis has been married seven times and has six children. His marriage to Myra Gale Brown was a scandal, and he has also been accused of abuse and neglect.

### Religious beliefs

Lewis is a devout Christian and has spoken publicly about the influence of his faith on his music and life.

### Graceland arrest

In 1976, Lewis was arrested at the gates of Elvis Presley's home, Graceland, while trying to visit his friend. Lewis was reportedly drunk and armed, and the incident was widely publicized.

### Debt

Lewis has struggled with debt throughout his life, including a significant tax debt to the IRS.

### Health and death

Lewis has ongoing health issues, including diabetes, arthritis, and heart problems. He has also struggled with addiction and depression. Lewis passed away on October 28, 2022, at the age of 87.

Selected discography
-------------------

### Compositions

Lewis has written or co-written many of his hit songs, including "Great Balls of Fire," "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," and "Breathless."

----------

article:
What Is a Woman?
================

What Is a Woman? is a documentary film that explores the concept of womanhood and femininity in the context of contemporary American society. The film delves into the complexities of gender identity, biological sex, and the social constructs that shape our understanding of what it means to be a woman.

Summary
--------

What Is a Woman? is a thought-provoking documentary that examines the nuances of womanhood through a series of interviews with experts, activists, and everyday individuals. The film raises important questions about the nature of femininity, the role of biology in shaping our understanding of sex and gender, and the ways in which societal norms and expectations influence our perceptions of womanhood. Through its exploration of these complex issues, the film aims to spark a nuanced and informed conversation about the meaning of womanhood in the 21st century.

Production
------------

### Development

The idea for What Is a Woman? was conceived by the film's director, who sought to create a documentary that would explore the complexities of womanhood in a way that was both accessible and thought-provoking. The director spent several months researching the topic, conducting interviews with experts and individuals from diverse backgrounds, and gathering footage that would help to illustrate the film's themes.

### Filming

Production on What Is a Woman? took place over the course of several months, during which time the director and her team traveled to various locations across the United States to conduct interviews and gather footage. The film features a diverse range of interview subjects, including experts in the fields of biology, psychology, and sociology, as well as activists, artists, and everyday individuals who share their personal experiences and perspectives on womanhood.

### Post-production

Following the completion of filming, the director and her team spent several months editing the footage and shaping the narrative of the film. The editing process involved selecting and arranging the interview footage, as well as adding visual elements such as animation and graphics to help illustrate the film's themes.

Release
--------

What Is a Woman? was released in the spring of 2022, premiering at a film festival in the United States. The film received widespread critical acclaim, with many reviewers praising its thought-provoking exploration of womanhood and its nuanced approach to complex issues. Following its festival premiere, the film was released in theaters and on streaming platforms, where it continued to generate buzz and spark conversation about the meaning of womanhood.

Reception
----------

### Critical response

What Is a Woman? received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many reviewers praising its thought-provoking exploration of womanhood and its nuanced approach to complex issues. Reviewers noted that the film was both accessible and informative, making it an excellent choice for viewers who were new to the topic as well as those who were already familiar with the issues.

### Audience response

Audiences responded enthusiastically to What Is a Woman?, with many viewers praising the film's thought-provoking exploration of womanhood and its nuanced approach to complex issues. The film sparked a lively conversation on social media, with many viewers sharing their own thoughts and perspectives on womanhood and the issues explored in the film.

2023–24 Arsenal F.C. Season

The 2023–24 season is Arsenal Football Club's 102nd season in the top division of English football and their 28th consecutive season in the Premier League. The club will compete in the Premier League, the FA Cup, the EFL Cup, and the UEFA Champions League.

**Review**

**Background**
The 2023–24 season marks the second season under the management of Mikel Arteta, who was appointed as the club's head coach in December 2019. The club finished the 2022–23 season in 2nd place in the Premier League, qualifying for the UEFA Champions League for the first time since the 2016–17 season.

**Pre-season**
Arsenal began their pre-season campaign with a tour of the United States, where they played against Major League Soccer teams FC Dallas and the Colorado Rapids. The club then returned to Europe, where they played against Inter Milan and Lyon in the Emirates Cup.

**First-team transfers (summer transfer window)**
During the summer transfer window, Arsenal signed several players, including goalkeeper David Raya from Brentford, midfielder Declan Rice from West Ham United, and forward Kai Havertz from Chelsea. The club also sold several players, including midfielder Granit Xhaka to Bayer Leverkusen and forward Nicolas Pépé to Trabzonspor.

**August**
The 2023–24 Premier League season began on August 12, 2023, with Arsenal facing off against Nottingham Forest at the Emirates Stadium. The club won the match 2–1, with goals from Gabriel Jesus and Bukayo Saka.

**September**
In September, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club drew 1–1 against Manchester United at Old Trafford, with a goal from Martin Ødegaard. Arsenal also won 2–1 against Aston Villa at the Emirates Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus and Bukayo Saka.

**October**
In October, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 3–1 against Tottenham Hotspur at the Emirates Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus, Martin Ødegaard, and Declan Rice. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Liverpool at Anfield, with a goal from Gabriel Jesus.

**November**
**Newcastle match, Arteta comments, FA charge and hearing**
On November 11, 2023, Arsenal played against Newcastle United at St James' Park. The match ended 0–0, but the club's head coach, Mikel Arteta, was charged by the Football Association (FA) for comments he made about the match referee. Arteta was found guilty and fined £15,000 by the FA.

**December**
In December, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 2–1 against West Ham United at the Emirates Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus and Bukayo Saka. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge, with a goal from Martin Ødegaard.

**January**
**First-team transfers (winter transfer window)**
During the winter transfer window, Arsenal signed several players, including midfielder Jorginho from Chelsea and forward Leandro Trossard from Brighton & Hove Albion. The club also sold several players, including midfielder Albert Sambi Lokonga to Crystal Palace and forward Folarin Balogun to Monaco.

**February**
In February, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 2–1 against Manchester City at the Emirates Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus and Martin Ødegaard. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Brentford at the Gtech Community Stadium, with a goal from Bukayo Saka.

**March**
In March, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 3–1 against Fulham at Craven Cottage, with goals from Gabriel Jesus, Martin Ødegaard, and Declan Rice. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Brighton & Hove Albion at the Emirates Stadium, with a goal from Gabriel Jesus.

**April**
In April, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 2–1 against Southampton at St Mary's Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus and Bukayo Saka. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium, with a goal from Martin Ødegaard.

**May**
In May, Arsenal played several matches in the Premier League and the UEFA Champions League. The club won 3–1 against Manchester United at the Emirates Stadium, with goals from Gabriel Jesus, Martin Ødegaard, and Declan Rice. Arsenal also drew 1–1 against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge, with a goal from Gabriel Jesus.

**June**
The 2023–24 season ended on June 2, 2024, with Arsenal finishing in 3rd place in the Premier League. The club qualified for the UEFA Champions League for the second consecutive season.

article:
2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship

The 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship was the ninth edition of the tournament, organized by the International Handball Federation (IHF), held in North Macedonia from 30 July to 11 August 2022.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship began in 2019, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament. North Macedonia was ultimately awarded the hosting rights, marking the country's first time hosting a major international handball tournament.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the tournament involved teams from six continents: Africa, Asia, Europe, North and Central America, Oceania, and South America. Teams competed in continental championships and qualification tournaments to secure their spots in the final tournament. A total of 32 teams qualified for the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship.

# Draw

The draw for the preliminary round was held on 12 May 2022, in Skopje, North Macedonia. The 32 participating teams were divided into eight groups of four teams each.

## Seeding

The teams were seeded based on their performance in previous IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championships and continental championships. The top eight teams from the previous tournament, the 2018 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship, were automatically seeded into the top pot. The remaining teams were seeded based on their continental championships and qualification tournaments.

# Squads

Lil Tay

Lil Tay was a Canadian social media personality and rapper who gained widespread attention and notoriety online, particularly among teenagers and young adults. Born Claire Hope, Lil Tay initially rose to fame through her Instagram and YouTube accounts, where she posted videos and photos that showcased her lavish lifestyle and provocative behavior. Her online presence sparked controversy and debate, with some hailing her as a bold and unapologetic figure, while others criticized her for promoting materialism and disrespecting her family.

#Early and personal life

Lil Tay was born Claire Hope on July 29, 2008, in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Little is known about her early life, as she rarely spoke about her childhood or family in interviews. However, it is reported that she grew up in a wealthy household with her parents, Angela and Christopher Hope, who owned a successful real estate business. Lil Tay's parents were often featured in her social media posts, with some accusing them of exploiting their daughter's online fame for personal gain.

#Career

##Social media beginning

Lil Tay created her Instagram account in 2015, when she was just seven years old. Initially, her account featured innocent posts about her childhood and family life. However, as she grew older, her content began to shift towards showcasing her wealthy lifestyle, with posts featuring luxury cars, designer clothing, and expensive jewelry. Her Instagram account quickly gained traction, and she became known for her bold and provocative posts, which often featured her using profanity and displaying a confident, unapologetic attitude.

##Coaching allegations and silence

In 2018, Lil Tay faced allegations that her parents were coaching her on what to say and do in her social media posts. Many critics accused her family of manipulating her online presence for financial gain, and that Lil Tay was not the mastermind behind her provocative content. In response to these allegations, Lil Tay went silent on social media, sparking rumors that her parents had taken control of her accounts. The controversy surrounding her coaching allegations led to a decline in her online popularity, with many of her fans turning against her.

##Familial conflict

In 2019, Lil Tay's family life was thrust into the spotlight when her parents, Angela and Christopher Hope, filed a lawsuit against each other over the management of their daughter's social media empire. The lawsuit alleged that Christopher Hope had been mismanaging Lil Tay's finances and exploiting her online fame for personal gain. The lawsuit sparked a public feud between Lil Tay's parents, with both sides accusing each other of manipulating their daughter for financial gain.

#Reception and influence

Lil Tay's online presence was met with both praise and criticism. Some hailed her as a bold and unapologetic figure who was unafraid to speak her mind and showcase her wealth. Others criticized her for promoting materialism and disrespecting her family. Despite the controversy surrounding her, Lil Tay's influence on social media was undeniable. She inspired a generation of young people to be bold and confident online, and her provocative content sparked important conversations about the impact of social media on society.

#Death hoax

In 2020, Lil Tay was the subject of a death hoax that spread rapidly across social media. The hoax claimed that she had died in a car accident, and many of her fans were left mourning her supposed passing. However, the hoax was quickly debunked, and Lil Tay took to social media to confirm that she was alive and well.

#Discography

##Singles

* "Money Way" (2018)
* "Gucci Gang" (2018)
* " Rolex" (2019)

##Promotional singles

* "Lil Tay" (2018)
* "Flexin" (2019)

article:
Military History of Canada

The military history of Canada encompasses the history of armed conflict in Canada and the military activities of Canadians beyond the country's borders. From the earliest days of European contact to the present, Canada has been involved in numerous wars, rebellions, and peacekeeping missions.

# Warfare pre-contact

Before the arrival of European colonizers, indigenous peoples in Canada engaged in warfare for various reasons, including territorial disputes, resource competition, and revenge. These conflicts often involved small groups of warriors and were typically resolved through negotiations or skirmishes.

## European contact

The arrival of European explorers and settlers in the 16th century introduced new technologies, diseases, and conflicts to indigenous populations. Early European-Canadian conflicts were often driven by competition for resources, trade, and territory.

# 17th century

## Beaver Wars

The Beaver Wars (1609-1701) were a series of conflicts between the French and their indigenous allies, including the Huron and Algonquin, against the Iroquois Confederacy. The wars were sparked by competition for control of the fur trade and access to beaver pelts, which were highly valued for their fur.

### 1609-1667

During this period, the French established a series of trading posts and missions in the Great Lakes region, which led to conflicts with the Iroquois. The French and their allies launched several attacks against Iroquois villages, but were ultimately unable to defeat them.

### 1668-1701

The Iroquois Confederacy, which included the Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, and Seneca nations, formed an alliance with the British to counter French influence in the region. The Iroquois launched a series of attacks against French and indigenous villages, leading to the destruction of several French missions and trading posts.

## Early British-French colonial hostilities

Tensions between British and French colonizers in North America led to several conflicts, including the Acadian Civil War and the seizure of Acadia by British forces.

### Acadian Civil War and its subsequent seizure

The Acadian Civil War (1640-1645) was a conflict between the French colonists of Acadia and the British colonists of New England. The war was sparked by a dispute over the border between the two colonies and ended with the seizure of Acadia by British forces.

## Anglo-Dutch Wars

The Anglo-Dutch Wars (1652-1674) were a series of conflicts between the British and Dutch empires, including several battles fought in North America. The wars were sparked by competition for trade and territory, and ended with the British gaining control of several Dutch colonies, including New Amsterdam (present-day New York City).

## Nine Years' War

The Nine Years' War (1688-1697) was a global conflict that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and French forces clashed in the Great Lakes region and the Maritime provinces.

### English-maritime Algonquians conflict

The English-maritime Algonquians conflict (1675-1676) was a conflict between British colonists and the Algonquin people of the Maritime provinces. The conflict was sparked by a dispute over trade and territory, and ended with the signing of a peace treaty.

# 18th century

## War of Spanish Succession

The War of Spanish Succession (1701-1714) was a global conflict that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and French forces clashed in the Great Lakes region and the Maritime provinces.

## Father Rale's War

Father Rale's War (1722-1725) was a conflict between British colonists and the Mi'kmaq people of the Maritime provinces. The conflict was sparked by a dispute over trade and territory, and ended with the signing of a peace treaty.

## Fox Wars

The Fox Wars (1701-1716) were a series of conflicts between the French and their indigenous allies, including the Fox and Sauk, against the British and their indigenous allies, including the Iroquois Confederacy. The wars were sparked by competition for control of the fur trade and access to the Great Lakes region.

## War of Austrian Succession

The War of Austrian Succession (1740-1748) was a global conflict that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and French forces clashed in the Great Lakes region and the Maritime provinces.

## Father Le Loutre's War

Father Le Loutre's War (1749-1755) was a conflict between British colonists and the Mi'kmaq people of the Maritime provinces. The conflict was sparked by a dispute over trade and territory, and ended with the signing of a peace treaty.

## Seven Years' War

The Seven Years' War (1756-1763) was a global conflict that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and French forces clashed in the Great Lakes region and the Maritime provinces.

### Early French success and Acadia

The French had early success in the war, capturing several British forts and trading posts in the Great Lakes region. However, the British ultimately gained the upper hand, capturing the French fortifications at Louisbourg and Quebec.

### British conquest of New France

The British conquest of New France (1760-1763) was the final campaign of the Seven Years' War in North America. The British captured the French fortifications at Montreal and Quebec, and ultimately forced the French to surrender.

## Pontiac's War

Pontiac's War (1763-1766) was a conflict between British colonists and several indigenous tribes, including the Ottawa, Ojibwe, and Potawatomi. The conflict was sparked by a dispute over trade and territory, and ended with the signing of a peace treaty.

## American Revolutionary War

The American Revolutionary War (1775-1783) was a global conflict that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and American forces clashed.

### Quebec and Nova Scotia

The British maintained control of Quebec and Nova Scotia throughout the war, despite several American attempts to capture the provinces.

### Consequences

The war led to the signing of the Treaty of Paris, which recognized American independence from Britain. However, the treaty also led to the forced relocation of several thousand Loyalists from the United States to Canada.

## French Revolutionary Wars

The French Revolutionary Wars (1792-1802) were a series of conflicts that involved several European powers, including the British, French, and Spanish. The wars were fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and French forces clashed in the Great Lakes region and the Maritime provinces.

# 19th century

## War of 1812

The War of 1812 (1812-1815) was a conflict between the British and American empires. The war was fought in several theaters, including North America, where British and American forces clashed.

### 1813

The British launched a series of attacks against American forts and trading posts in the Great Lakes region, capturing the American fortifications at Detroit and Mackinac Island.

### 1814

The Americans launched a counterattack, capturing the British fortifications at York (present-day Toronto) and burning down several buildings, including the Parliament Buildings.

## Pemmican War

The Pemmican War (1814) was a conflict between the British and the Métis people of the Red River Valley. The conflict was sparked by a dispute over trade and territory, and ended with the signing of a peace treaty.

## British forces in Canada in the mid–19th century

The British maintained a significant military presence in Canada throughout the 19th century. The British forces in Canada were responsible for defending the country against American attacks and maintaining order in the face of growing nationalism and rebellion.

### Local levies and recruitment

The British relied on local levies and recruitment to maintain their military presence in Canada. The British recruited soldiers from among the Canadian population, including the French-Canadian and English-Canadian communities.

## Rebellions of 1837–1838

The Rebellions of 1837–1838 were a series of uprisings against British rule in Canada. The rebellions were sparked by a dispute over governance and representation, and ended with the defeat of the rebels.

## Conflicts during the Fraser Canyon Gold Rush

The Fraser Canyon Gold Rush (1858-1861) was a gold rush that took place in the Fraser Canyon region of British Columbia. The gold rush led to several conflicts between the British and indigenous peoples, including the Stó:lō and Nlaka'pamux.

## American Civil War

The American Civil War (1861-1865) was a conflict between the Union and Confederacy in the United States. The war had significant implications for Canada, including the Fenian raids and the British decision to grant Canada self-government.

## Fenian raids

The Fenian raids (1866-1871) were a series of attacks launched by Irish-American militants against British targets in Canada. The raids were sparked by a desire to establish an independent Irish republic and ended with the defeat of the Fenians.

## British forces in Canada in the late–19th century

article:
The Masked Singer (American TV series) season 7

The seventh season of the American reality singing competition television series The Masked Singer premiered on March 9, 2022, on Fox. The season featured a new format, with a theme of "Royal Season", where the contestants competed in teams, known as "royal courts", instead of individually. The season also introduced new characters, costumes, and challenges.

# Panelists and host

The panelists for the seventh season consisted of Ken Jeong, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Nicole Scherzinger, and Robin Thicke, who all returned from the previous season. The host of the show was also returning, Nick Cannon.

# Contestants

The seventh season featured 15 contestants, divided into three teams of five members each. The contestants were:

Team Good: Firefly, Prince, Ringmaster, Space Cowboy, and The Lemur
Team Bad: Hydra, The Lemur, Ram, Space Cowboy, and The Prince
Team Cuddly: Baby Mammoth, The Prince, Ram, The Lemur, and Space Cowboy

The contestants were a mix of celebrities from different fields, including music, film, television, and sports.

# Episodes

## Week 1 (March 9)

The season premiere introduced the 15 contestants and the three teams. The episode featured performances from all the contestants, and the first elimination took place at the end of the episode. The eliminated contestant was Space Cowboy from Team Bad.

## Week 2 (March 16)

The second episode saw the remaining 14 contestants performing in their teams. The episode featured a special guest judge, Joel McHale, who joined the panel for the week. The eliminated contestant was The Lemur from Team Cuddly.

## Week 3 (March 23)

In the third episode, the contestants performed in their teams, with a special theme of "80s Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Boyz II Men, who performed their hit song "End of the Road". The eliminated contestant was Ram from Team Bad.

## Week 4 (March 30)

The fourth episode saw the contestants performing in their teams, with a special theme of "Andrew Lloyd Webber Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Andrew Lloyd Webber himself, who performed a medley of his hits. The eliminated contestant was The Prince from Team Good.

## Week 5 (April 6)

In the fifth episode, the contestants performed in their teams, with a special theme of "Muppets Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy, who performed a duet of "Rainbow Connection". The eliminated contestant was Firefly from Team Good.

## Week 6 (April 13)

The sixth episode saw the contestants performing in their teams, with a special theme of "Country Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Dolly Parton, who performed her hit song "Jolene". The eliminated contestant was Ringmaster from Team Good.

## Week 7 (April 20)

In the seventh episode, the contestants performed in their teams, with a special theme of "Famous Duets Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Donny and Marie Osmond, who performed a duet of "I'm Leaving It All Up to You". The eliminated contestant was Baby Mammoth from Team Cuddly.

## Week 8 (April 27)

The eighth episode saw the contestants performing in their teams, with a special theme of "Comedy Night". The episode featured a guest performance by Will Ferrell, who performed a comedy sketch. The eliminated contestant was Hydra from Team Bad.

## Week 9 (May 4)

In the ninth episode, the contestants performed in their teams, with a special theme of "Semi-Finals". The episode featured a guest performance by LeAnn Rimes, who performed her hit song "Can't Fight the Moonlight". The eliminated contestant was The Lemur from Team Cuddly.

## Week 10 (May 18)

The season finale saw the remaining three contestants performing in the final episode. The episode featured a special performance by the eliminated contestants, who performed a medley of their songs. The winner of the season was announced as Firefly, who was revealed to be a famous singer.

# Ratings

The seventh season of The Masked Singer averaged a 2.5 rating in the 18-49 demographic and 8.3 million viewers per episode, making it one of the highest-rated shows of the season.

# Controversy

The seventh season of The Masked Singer was marred by controversy when one of the contestants, Space Cowboy, was eliminated in the first episode despite receiving a higher number of votes than another contestant, The Lemur. The incident sparked outrage on social media, with fans accusing the show of rigging the results.

# Notes

The seventh season of The Masked Singer was the first season to feature a team format, where contestants competed in teams instead of individually. The season also introduced new characters, costumes, and challenges.
